intro: Apargia autumnalis, commonly known as the autumn alumroot, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to the eastern United States. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its finely divided, fern-like leaves. The plant produces small, white to pale purple flowers in umbels, typically blooming in late summer to early autumn. Its roots are rich in potassium and have been historically used in traditional medicine. Apargia autumnalis thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in woodland habitats.
